title: Denmark says there's a 'fundamental disagreement' with Trump over Greenland
desc: The two sides agreed to create a working group to discuss ways to work through differences as President Trump continues to call for a U.S. takeover of Denmark's Arctic territory of Greenland.

title: Kitchen countertop workers are dying. Some lawmakers want to ban their lawsuits
desc: Some safety experts want California to stop the cutting of quartz countertops saying it can't be done safely. Lawmakers, meanwhile, contemplate a ban on workers' lawsuits against quartz manufacturers.

title: Candidates have legal standing to challenge election laws, the Supreme Court rules
desc: In a case related to Illinois state law about the return of mail ballots, the U.S. Supreme Court says political candidates have the legal standing to challenge election policies.

title: Scientists call another near-record hot year a 'warning shot' from a shifting climate
desc: Scientists calculate that last year was one of the three hottest on record, along with 2024 and 2023. The trend indicates that warming could be speeding up, climate monitoring teams reported.

title: MLK concert held annually at the Kennedy Center for 23 years is relocating
desc: Georgetown is moving Let Freedom Ring , its annual event celebrating the life of Martin Luther King, Jr., to the historic Howard Theatre in order to save money, the university said.

title: Democrat Elissa Slotkin says she is under investigation for video on illegal orders
desc: Michigan Democratic Sen. Elissa Slotkin says she is under federal investigation for posting a video urging members of the military not to obey illegal orders.

title: How Marco Rubio shifted from Trump critic to Trump champion
desc: Rubio once called Trump a "con artist." He's now among his most loyal defenders. New Yorker writer Dexter Filkins describes Secretary of State Rubio's character, political transformation and ambition.

title: Trump administration sends letter wiping out addiction, mental health grants
desc: The Trump administration sent hundreds of letters Tuesday terminating federal grants supporting mental health and drug addiction services. The cuts could total as much as $2 billion.
